Second topic: The Congressional Black Caucus and the Service Employees International Union have been in a sparring match about Wal-Mart, that SEIU wants the Congressional Black Caucus to stand up to Wal-Mart, but what we're hearing from Elijah Cummings and other members of the Caucus is `No.
Why, Donna?

Well, first of all, I think members of the Black Caucus are deeply aware of the problems at Wal-Mart, the fact that Wal-Mart pays their workers very low wages, they're also concerned that Wal-Mart does not provide the health-care benefits to its workers.

The Congressional Black Caucus received a letter from the Service Employees International Union calling upon the members of the Caucus not to meet with Wal-Mart, not to allow Wal-Mart to host their events, and many--some members of the CBC took offense at SEIU's letter.

They thought it was offensive, they thought that SEIU should have called members of the Black Caucus and talked to them individually and privately, and they shot off a letter back to SEIU, basically, saying, `Butt out.
We know how to conduct our politics.'
Well, wait a second now.

We know that over the last few years now, what we see is the Congressional Black Caucus becoming less predictable in terms of its voting record, but, on Wal-Mart, I think, the SEIU figured `You're gonna back us,' a strong union that always has backed the Congressional Back Caucus.
So many members of SEIU are minorities, black people, so how can the Caucus separate from a key constituency?
